p:
CO2 emissions were the primary factor increasing Australia’s ecological footprint during the studied period. As Table 2 illustrates, the effect of CO2 emissions on the ecological footprint became more dominant between 1990 and 2017. More than 60% of the ecological footprint resulted from the increase in CO2 emissions, after 2000. Other factors affecting the ecological footprint were buildup land, cropland, forest products, grazing land, and fishing grounds (GFN, 2020).Table.2
Share of carbon footprint in ecological footprint of Australia
1990200020102017
Carbon footprint (gha)73,898,291.7193,204,060.1121,594,174.06109,454,148.38
Ecological footprint (gha)136,688,324.68152,982,541.25181,824,032.12177,820,594.01
Share (%)54.160.966.961.6
Carbon footprint, with its general definition, is the calculation of the amount of greenhouse gas that is directly or indirectly generated as a result of human activities, with the equivalent of carbon dioxide (CO2) and in tons.
